title: Dealing with a crisis? Call Paul, Weiss
text:
One deep-dive to start: since its £856m London listing, Alphawave has remained the UK's most valuable company in the semiconductor sector. But for a fast-growing enterprise now worth billions of pounds, its key clients seem a little too close to home, as the FT's Jamie Powell and DD's Rob Smith explore in this Alphaville post. The company's shares more than halved after it was published.

https://twitter.com/BondHack/status/1443234316822196230

The elite US law firm that specialises in corporate crises

When allegations of misconduct threaten an enterprise's business and brand and raise the spectre of government action, companies and boards turn to Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.

DD didn't come up with that sentence: it's attorney advertising, which we lifted verbatim from the website of one of America's most prestigious law firms.

A pitch like that might be the reason why the board of the online media start-up Ozy hired Paul, Weiss this week, shortly after The New York Times reported that the company's co-founder had impersonated a YouTube executive in an apparent attempt to attract investment from Goldman Sachs.

Or maybe the Ozy board was simply impressed with the credentials of the firm's chair Brad Karp.

Since starting as a summer associate, Karp has become one of the nation's most prominent corporate lawyers.

He has also cultivated a reputation as a courtroom crusader for social justice. The “profoundly human dimension in this struggle to uphold the rule of law”, he said while accepting a prestigious award in 2019, “should not be lost”.

Still, the work that Paul, Weiss does for corporate clients calls for pragmatism as often as profundity.

According to its website, the firm's advice has helped “the world's most prominent companies . . .[to] avoid full-scale regulatory actions, and limit legal and reputational exposure”.

Soaring rhetoric it isn't, but that pitch seems to have won over some impressive clients.

Fox hired Paul, Weiss to investigate claims that its star anchor Bill O'Reilly had harassed several women. (O'Reilly denied the allegations. He was later taken off the air, and received a big payout.)

Credit Suisse hired Paul, Weiss to produce a 165-page report into its financially ruinous relationship with the stricken investment group Archegos Capital Management. (The lawyers identified a “failure of management” but “ultimately . . . no evidence of fraud”.)

And BlackRock has hired Paul, Weiss to investigate reports of “employee misconduct” after the FT and other publications detailed allegations of discrimination and sexual harassment at the world's biggest asset manager.

Of course, it often happens that the allegations that Paul, Weiss is hired to investigate turn out to be unfounded.

Consider the case of Apollo Global Management, a longtime client that hired Karp's firm in 2012 to look at possible irregularities in its expenses system.

One Apollo partner, who was later fired, ended up paying back $290,000 to Apollo investors. But Apollo itself discovered it had undercharged investors to the tune of $370,000.

The final showdown in a £10bn private equity bidding war 

After months of duelling for control of the UK supermarket chain Wm Morrison, an auction this weekend will determine the winner.

The £10bn stand-off pits the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice against the SoftBank-owned Fortress Investment Group, which is best known for its bets in the distressed debt market.

The showdown amounts to the most high-profile auction in the UK takeover arena since Comcast and Disney fought for control of the pay-TV broadcaster Sky. For those interested in the precise mechanics of this weekend's auction, go here.

As we've already explained in DD, supermarkets in the UK hold some sort of strange psychological grip on the country and its newspapers.

Based on media coverage alone, you'd be forgiven for thinking Morrisons was something more than just the fourth-largest UK grocery chain by sales with a less-than-ambitious online footprint compared to its rivals. Though its new partnership with Deliveroo could signal efforts to modernise the group and keep up with the boom in “rapid” grocery delivery apps.

Both PE firms are now looking at offering more than a 60 per cent premium to the company's undisturbed share price. (Including debt, that means any deal for Morrisons will value the company at well over £10bn.)

We're used to seeing those kinds of numbers for a hot biotech start-up, not a neighbourhood retailer colloquially referred to by Brits as “Mozzas”. 

For some, the saga has highlighted how a mismatch between the value public market shareholders have ascribed versus what private market investors are willing to pay.

But DD wonders if this deal will come to be remembered as the high-point of a dry powder-fuelled private equity bubble soon to burst, with the macroeconomic backdrop beginning to darken.

Look at the private equity scrap unfolding in Germany for the online petcare retailer ZooPlus. The Swedish buyout firm EQT has topped its opponent Hellman & Friedman with an offer that values it a 69 per cent premium.

There's either something seriously inefficient with public markets, or the private equity business has become overstimulated.

Like most dealmaking dramas, however, it's important to remember that the real winners from any takeover battle are the bankers, lawyers and other advisers.

Late last week, Morrisons released its shareholders documents as it relates to the current recommended offer from CD&R. As you can see from the image above, advisers and financiers working with CD&R are set to take home more than £300m in fees.

Leading the pack is Anthony Gutman at Goldman Sachs, whose bank is likely taking a huge portion of the deal's financing alongside JPMorgan Chase. We also note the tidy chunk of change headed over to the folks at Teneo who are handling media and public relations for CD&R. We've previously covered the fees for the Fortress camp here.

The stage is set for Saturday at 5pm UK time. You can only imagine how frustrated the losing camp will be.

Are venture capitalists the new financial engineers?

General Catalyst has a record of predicting the next big thing.

The Cambridge-based venture capital heavyweight got in early on some of the tech world's hottest companies, including Stripe, Airbnb and Lemonade. It's latest win came on Wednesday following the soaring public debut of the eyewear group Warby Parker, which it invested in almost a decade ago.

So DD wonders if its latest endeavour will catch on: Structured Opportunities, a new bout of financial engineering in which it purchases sales contracts from tech start-ups to gain a slice of their future revenue streams.

The venture capital firm intends to raise up to $300m for its first structured opportunities fund, and has already begun making investment offers out of the strategy, one person briefed on the matter told DD's Miles Kruppa.

As it turns out, General Catalyst isn't the only firm trying this strategy.

A new crop of start-ups have emerged that allow companies to sell rights to their future revenue streams for discounted sums upfront. They include groups such as Capchase and Pipe.

If that business model sounds slightly familiar, you might be thinking of Greensill Capital, the SoftBank-backed group that allowed companies to forward-sell their invoices and spectacularly imploded earlier this year.

Job moves

  • General Motors chief executive Mary Barra has been named as the first female chair of the non-profit lobbying group Business Roundtable, succeeding Walmart chief Doug McMillon.

  • Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer has hired Damien Zoubek as its new co-head of US corporate and M&A, based in New York. Zoubek, who has been a partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore since 2007, is the latest star dealmaker to defect to a rival amid a talent war between elite US and UK firms.

  • The billionaire Patrick Drahi has poached BNP Paribas veteran Laurence Beghin to lead investments at Next Alt, Drahi's personal investment vehicle, per Bloomberg.
